awd_titl_txt: ICE-T: RC: Multi-Domain Multi-Broker Elastic Optical Networks with Cognitive Functionalities
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project seeks an innovative approach to the design, control and management of next generation Internet core networks. A new inter-domain networking paradigm is considered, where broker agents compete freely with each other to provide attractive inter-networking services to Autonomous Systems (ASes), while ASes also choose broker services suitable for their inter-networking needs.

The project develops a market-driven multi-broker-assisted multi-domain framework that can coordinate -- in a distributed, incentivized manner - while providing complete autonomy and freedom to both brokers and ASes. Through market-driven incentives and competitions, the brokers and the ASes will pursue mutually beneficial services, which will in turn continuously spur innovative solutions and services.  The new inter-domain networking architecture with multiple brokers will facilitate automated, Quality-of-Service aware, and impairment-responsive services. The project leverages cognitive functionalities based on machine learning to optimize end-to-end service provisioning. 

The project seeks to architect, simulate, prototype, and experiment to improve system (a) scalability, (b) end-to-end performance, (c) robustness and adaptability, and (d) manageability and coordination.  The project will leverage novel and emerging cognitive techniques for dynamic traffic prediction and adaptive provisioning, quality of transmission estimation and fault detection across multiple domains. This project extends a research collaboration between the University of California, David, the Universitat Politecnica de Cataluna (UPC), Spain, and Consorzio Nazionale and Interuniversitario per le Telecomunicazioni (CNIT), Italy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

This NSF-funded project achieved significant advancements in the design and management of optical and quantum communication networks, paving the way for more efficient, secure, and scalable data transmission systems. The project integrated cutting-edge theoretical models, machine learning, and experimental validations to address critical challenges in these fields. Key contributions include:

  1. Optimizing Multi-Domain Network Architectures:
    • Developed a game-theoretic framework to optimize resource allocation in multi-domain elastic optical networks, ensuring efficient service provisioning while preserving data privacy. This system modeled network interactions dynamically to enhance resource utilization.
  2. Machine Learning for Enhanced Networking:
    • Designed and implemented advanced machine learning algorithms to optimize data routing and quality of transmission (QoT) predictions. These included distributed and hierarchical learning frameworks that improved inter-domain service provisioning.
    • Explored deep reinforcement learning (DRL) techniques to create autonomous network management systems, reducing human intervention and achieving lower blocking probabilities in service requests.
  3. Advanced Fault Detection Mechanisms:
    • Introduced hybrid learning methods to detect and localize faults in networks with high accuracy (up to 97%). These mechanisms utilized federated learning to maintain privacy across domains while ensuring effective fault management.
  4. Innovative Quantum Network Designs:
    • Developed Quantum Wrapper Networks (QWN) for the seamless coexistence of classical and quantum data streams. This innovation demonstrated high performance, including low error rates and high signal visibility, during experimental validations.
    • Designed and implemented Quantum Digital Twin (QDT) systems to improve the reliability of quantum key distribution (QKD) networks, addressing real-world imperfections in devices and transmission channels.
  5. Experimental Testbeds:
    • Established experimental setups to evaluate hybrid quantum-classical networks. These testbeds demonstrated capabilities such as dynamic rerouting, fault-tolerant data transport, and efficient quantum payload handling over extended fiber links.

These contributions have addressed major challenges in resource optimization, fault tolerance, and the integration of quantum and classical networks, setting a foundation for future innovations in communication technologies.

Broader Impacts

  1. Educational Contributions:
    • Incorporated research findings into undergraduate and graduate curricula, particularly in courses focused on optical communications and quantum networking, enriching the learning experience for students.
  2. International Collaboration:
    • Fostered meaningful research partnerships between the University of California, Davis, and European institutions (e.g., Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya in Spain and Consorzio Nazionale Interuniversitario per le Telecomunicazioni in Italy). These collaborations facilitated cross-cultural knowledge exchange and interdisciplinary innovation, greatly enriching the project’s impact.
  3. Workforce Development:
    • Trained students and early-career researchers in state-of-the-art methodologies for optical and quantum communication systems, equipping them with the skills needed for advanced careers in academia and industry.
  4. Dissemination of Knowledge:
    • Published over 15 peer-reviewed papers in high-impact journals and conferences, earning accolades such as best paper awards. Results were shared at international conferences, fostering collaboration and global knowledge exchange.

Concluding Remarks

This project delivered significant advancements in optical and quantum communication technologies, bridging theoretical innovation and practical implementation. By addressing resource allocation, fault management, and quantum-classical integration, the research outcomes promise lasting benefits for academia, industry, and society, laying the groundwork for future breakthroughs in secure and efficient communication systems.
